prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We seek total intensity imaging at 870 microns - the standard Band 7, dual polarization setup with 31MHz channels meets our scientific requirements, while producing a trivial data rate of 2.4MB/s (3.2GB for 0.6h of observations).

We seek 870 micron observations at 0.2" resolution in order to facilitate direct comparison with the C-band radio continuum and CO(1-0) molecular gas emission, both observed at this resolution with JVLA. Given the 37.5x lensing in The Eyelash (at z=2.3), 0.2" in the image plane corresponds to a physical size of ~100pc, comparable to giant molecular cloud complexes - the locations of active star formation - in nearby star-forming galaxies. Our largest angular scale of 3.9" will allow us to recover flux from across the entire face of the galaxy (roughly 0.5"x3.9", in our JVLA CO(1-0) imaging) in a single pointing.
The use of ACA is not recommended by the OT, so we do not request it.

As per the 450 micron case, we begin by considering the total single-dish S_870 = 106 +/- 7mJy from Swinbank et al. (2010).
In order to reliably determine the dust morphology of the source, we aim for S/N > 10 per beam. We estimate the required sensitivity by invoking the conservative assumption that this emission is spread diffusely throughout the same 0.5x4" region as is traced by our CO observations (Thomson et al, 2015; and Fig 1, this proposal). In this case, the 0.2" ALMA observations for which we propose will resolve the emission across ~50 beams. To reach 10\sigma, we therefore require an rms sensitivity of 0.21mJy/beam. If the emission is clumpy (see description of 450 micron science goals for details of the assumed geometry), then these observations will yield S/N > 20.

We require total intensity continuum obesrvations in Band 9 - the standard dual polarization setup with 31MHz channels satisfies our scentific requirements, while delivering a manageable datarate of 2.4MB/s (17.5GB after 3.1 hours).

Our existing SMA 870micron continuum image, made from the most extended configuration data has an angular resolution of 0.3", and hints that up to 80% of the total single-dish flux resides within eight unresolved image-plane clumps, however the poor uv coverage makes the fidelity of the image uncertain. Our 0.2" JVLA CO(1-0) datacube also detects unresolved gas clumps, albeit with slight positional offsets with respect to those seen in the SMA image. With ALMA Band 9, we will achieve our highest-resolution observations of the ISM in the Eyelash to date (0.1", or 50pc in the source plane), with adequate signal to noise (and uv coverage) to search for and reliably identify clumpy dust emission, quantifing the contributions of clumpy versus extended dust emission. Our observations will also allow us to constrain the clump sizes down to the scales of individual giant molecular clouds.
The OT does not recommend the use of ACA, and so we do not select it.

In order to robustly measure the contribution to S_450 (rest-frame 140 microns) coming from compact, clumpy versus extended emission, we aim for a S/N of >10\sigma in each 0.1" beam. We estimate the required sensitivity by considering the SCUBA-2 single dish flux of S_450 = 480 +/- 54mJy (Ivison et al, 2010), and assuming that this flux traces a region roughly 0.5x4" in size (similar to the CO gas reservoir; Thomson et al, 2015; Fig 1, this proposal).
Our most conservative assumption is that the emission is predominantly diffuse, in which case our 0.1" ALMA observations will resolve the total flux across ~200 beams. To reach 10\sigma, we thus require an rms sensitivity of 0.24mJy/beam. At the opposite extreme, if the emission is predominantly clumpy (as implied by our existing SMA data, albeit with very limited uv coverage; Swinbank et al, 2010), we may see up to 80% of the total S_450 in eight image plane clumps. If the clumps remain unresolved with 0.1" ALMA observations, then the faintest clump (~15mJy) will be detected at ~60 sigma.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(3-2) and 3mm continuum imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High angular and spectral resolution imaging of redshifted CO(3-2) line emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our key science goal is to measure the gas properties on giant molecular cloud scales, via the CO(3-2) line. To do this, we require a spectral resolution which adequately covers the expected linewidths of the clumps (~80 - 100km/s). We opt for 3.9MHz (11km/s) channels in one baseband, which will cover the full extent of the CO line, providing 7-9 resolution elements across the width of each clump line profile.
These data will also allow us to measure the line profile of the entire galaxy, which will be exquisitely well sampled, with ~54 resolution elements covering the 600km/s FWZI.
We will place the other three basebands on either side of the line. Using coarse 31MHz channels over 3x1.875GHz regions at a representative 100GHz central frequency, the 50 minutes of on-source time dictated by our CO requirements will yield a 3mm continuum sensitivity of 16 microJy/beam.
Together, these observations will produce a data rate of 1.4MB/s (21.9GB in 4.5h).

We request 0.2" resolution CO(3-2) imaging to facilitate comparison with our existing CO(1-0) and C-band JVLA imaging, and with our high-resolution dust mapping (this proposal). These observations will allow us to spatially-resolve the molecular gas emission in this lensed, z=2.3 starburst galaxy on ~100pc scales.
The goals of achieving 0.2" clump-scale resolution while remaining sensitive to emisison on 4" scales (to cover the full disk) are incompatible within a single-pointing setup. We therefore adopt a mosaic strategy comprising two pointings separated by ~1.4" along the position angle of the Eyelash, each of which will be sensitive to emission on ~1.5" scales, allowing us to recover the total flux in the source.

We have measured the total CO(3-2) flux in The Eyelash via coarse angular resolution (~3") PdBI imaging (Danielson et al, 2011). In order to study the spatially resolved gas excitation properties - and thus probe the conditions of ongoing star formation - we require kinematically-resolved CO(3-2) observations at angular resolution comparable to that of our existing CO(1-0), (6-5) and radio continuum maps.
The PdBI results yield a total integrated CO(3-2) flux density of 22mJy (30mJy at the line peak). We find that around 50% of the JVLA CO(1-0) flux lies within 8 image-plane clumps with sizes <0.3" and velocity FWHM ~ 100km/s (Thomson et al, 2015). Given the excitation requirements of the 3-2 line, we expect a similar (or larger) fraction of the total 3-2 emission (i.e. > 11mJy) will also lie within these dense clumps. With detections of line emission from the clumps at 5\sigma, we will be able to measure the velocity widths and centroids of the clumps (relative to the systemic velocity gradient in the Eyelash). To do this, we require data reaching a depth of ~0.28mJy across the 100km/s clump linewidths, or 0.6mJy per 11km/s channel.
We have chosen a representative line width for the clumps of 100km/s, which is measured from our CO(1-0) datacube. The 11km/s channel width will thus give us ~9 resolution elements per clump line, with ~54 resolution elements covering the full 600km/s linewidth of the Eyelash.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose Band 7 and 9 continuum imaging, and Band 3 CO(3-2) spectral line imaging in the strongly lensed z=2.3 star-forming galaxy, SMMJ21352-0102 ("The Cosmic Eyelash"). The strong, 37.5x gravitational lensing of this source by the foreground cluster, combined with the high angular resolution (~0.1") of extended configuration ALMA observations will allow us to probe the ISM on ~50pc scales, approaching the sizes of individual giant molecular clouds. Using the off-spectral line portion of our Band 3 observations, we will - at no additional cost of telescope time - create a high sensitivity 0.2" 3mm continuum image of the Eyelash. These observations will probe rest-frame 140, 260 and 1000 micron emission, allowing us to construct a spatially-resolved far-IR SED in this galaxy, measuring the star formation efficiency of GMC-scale gas clumps, and creating maps of dust mass and temperature. Together with existing JVLA CO(1-0) and C-band continuum observations at comparable resolution, we will study the spatially-resolved gas excitation and fuelling of star formation in this strongly-lensed, but otherwise "typical" high-redshift star-forming galaxy.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.01029.S, "50pc resolution mapping of a unique strongly lensed z=2.3 sub-mm galaxy", PI: Danielson, A
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
Astrophysics Research Institute, Liverpool John Moores University
Laboratory for Millimeter-Wave Astronomy, Maryland, University of
